bioghist.p: Richard Phillips Leary (1842-1901) was an admiral in the United States Navy who served from the American Civil War through the Spanish-American War. Leary entered the United States Naval Academy in 1860. During the Civil War, he served in screw sloop Canandaigua and monitor Sangamon assigned to the Atlantic blockade. The USS Adams was commissioned to the Pacific Station in 1885 and cruised along the west coast and in Hawaiian and Samoan waters. During tension with Germany over Samoa, Leary commanded the USS Adams at Samoa from October to December 1888. In the Spanish-American War, he commanded the San Francisco (C-5) off Havana, Cuba. From 1899 to 1900, Captain Leary served as Naval Governor of Guam. Retiring in 1901, Rear Admiral Leary died 27 December at Chelsea, Mass. In 1943, the destroyer USS Richard P. Leary (DD-664) was named in his honor.

scopecontent.p: Leatherbound letterbook of Captain R.P. Leary, US Navy, 1896, 1888-1889, and 1899-1900. Includes correspondence while Leary was captain of the USS Adams and during his tenure as Governor of Guam. The volume also includes Leary's printed proclamations and general orders. The correspondence from the USS Adams describes conditions in Samoa, attacks on American property, and the rebellion led by Chief Tamasese. The correspondence from Guam includes reports to the Secretary of the Navy on military and civil affairs. These reports also discuss outbreaks of typhoid fever and other medical matters and request supplies and machinery. Other letters relate to staff postings and personnel matters and orders for USS Yosemite, USS Brutus, and other vessels. Proclamations include the announcement of the US occupation and administration of Guam, the outlawing of the practice concubinage; prohibition of the sale of "any intoxicating stimulant, liquid, gelatinous, or solid"; and the abolition of slavery. There are copies of proclamations in English, Spanish, and Chomarro. Some letters relate to issues of religious liberty in Guam under Leary's governorship. Leary expelled a number of Catholic friars from Guam, arguing that they had too much influence on native officials. The collection also includes; a telegram (in code); a passenger list of the US Mail Steamer St. Paul, 1900; copies of general orders of Leary as Governor of Guam, 1899-1900; and several additional letters.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
